resources.string:
Morse code is a method used in telecommunication to encode text characters as sequences of two different signal durations, such as dots and dashes. Morse code symbols consist of these basic elements:
1. Dot (.): Represented as a short signal or sound. In audio communication, its typically a short beep or click.
2. Dash (-): Represented as a longer signal or sound. In audio communication, its a longer tone or click.
Morse code uses combinations of dots and dashes to represent letters, numbers, and some special characters. Here are some common Morse code symbols:
Letters (A-Z):
A: .- N: -. 0: ----- B: -... O: --- 1: .---- C: -.-. P: .--. 2: ..--- D: -.. Q: --.- 3: ...-- E: . R: .-. 4: ....- F: ..-. S: ... 5: ..... G: --. T: - 6: -.... H: .... U: ..- 7: --... I: .. V: ...- 8: ---.. J: .--- W: .-- 9: ----. K: -.- X: -..- L: .-.. Y: -.-- M: -- Z: --..
Arabic numerals (0-9):
1: .---- 2: ..--- 3: ...-- 4: ....- 5: ..... 6: -.... 7: --... 8: ---.. 9: ----. 0: -----
